Workshop at Frontyard: Dynamic Climates

Saturday, Feb 15 at Frontyard, 228 Illawarra Rd, Marrickville NSW 2204
2-4pm


It’s been hot and it’s only getting hotter. We have different experiences of heat, and different ways of living with it.

The thermal dynamics of hormone and climate fluctuations re-casts ‘climate change’ as an intimate experience, linking our diverse bodies and environments. Aside from the escape hatch of climate-controlled environments, we reach for or rely on physical, sensory things around us, that we use, inhabit or don, for support. At best these ‘climatic objects’ assist and comfort, and, at worst, they can amplify our fears about our capacity to weather the ‘weather to come‘.

This workshop is about exploring how we weather dynamic climates, inside and out with climatic objects, which might be a hammock or a hat, a piece of visual art or music, a bicycle, a bodily movement, a slice of watermelon, a fan. Hormonal fluctuations of bodies can be thought of as the body’s own weather from childhood to end-of-life, influencing feeling and experience. Our bodies are not usually naked to the world but wrapped and nested in other environments - from garments to dwellings, which subtly or overtly, affect us.

Instruction for participants: Bring a portable object (or a picture of it) or a performance to the workshop that will help you to tell a story about experiencing dynamic climates that only you can tell.

This object might connect you to a place, body, practice or condition, living with thermal fluctuations (heat, humidity, sweat, chill, wind, dry, wet) and reflect your experiences of weathering dynamic climates inside and out. Or it might reflect how external encounters with weather affects our interactions with things and intersects with the dynamic hormones and weather felt by our bodies.

Katherine Moline (she/they), School of Art & Design, UNSW, Sydney. kat_moline
Abby Mellick Lopes (she/her/hers), School of Design, UTS, Sydney. @abs_lopes
Alison Gill (she/her/hers), Design, Western Sydney University. @alisongilli2

currently on residency @frontyardorg dreaming up a new Eora based zine created by trans and gender diverse ppl,, thinking about recreating those library books you’d borrow at school littered with notes/annotations/musings of others from 20 years back. I’m trans bc you’re trans and we’re trans and I wanna not just put together a bunch of people who happen to be trans but also to look at how process/sharing/co-creation also creates us!

now i need contributors !! anyone of any artistic background and level of experience encouraged to apply (only requirement being that this project is autonomous to trans, gender diverse and questioning people)

Please please share around! Expression of interest linked in my bio, DM me if you have any questions!

Hi friends,

I am hosting another group Tarot reading session at Frontyard on Saturday November 23rd 3-5pm. Come along!

This is the third in a series of readings focusing on a keyword. Last time, we spoke about RAGE. The guiding word for this session will be CRISIS. See blurb below.  

The way I practice Tarot is slightly different to a traditional Tarot reading. In a typical one-on-one reading, the querent (or questioner) comes to the reader with a problem for which they are seeking guidance. The reader lays out a spread and interprets the cards, tailoring the reading to the querent’s mindset.

I read with small and large groups of people. Together, we formulate a question based on our shared feelings, problems, and ideas. I facilitate the reading, but I try not to exert too much control. For me, a group Tarot reading is akin to the best tutorial discussions―rigorous, probing, collaborative, compassionate, energising, unsettling. I like that Tarot opens a space for interpretation and negotiation. You don’t need to know much about Tarot to participate!

?

I am growing skeptical of the word ‘crisis’. I think, read, and write the word crisis on a near daily basis. To invoke the language of crisis is to summon a heightened emotional state, a sense of urgency, a will to act. Polycrisis refers to the intermingling of crises. However, it’s a language that feels strangely inadequate, a generic signifier of badness that masks specific and material conditions. Does it offer meaningful choices or does it perpetuate reactive tendencies? I have come to think of crisis as a blockage, where intensity accumulates with nowhere to go. What could replace the word crisis? Do we need new forms, languages, and practices to overcome this paralysis? 

If any of this resonates with you, come along and we’ll work it out together. ?

Piece by Piece was incredible! ?? Thank you to everyone who came out for our collage workshop ― it was a beautiful few hours of creativity, connection, and play. We blurred the lines between dreams and waking life, crafting with magazines, old books, and personal touches brought by the group. ?????

We shared untold stories, sparked conversations, and walked away with hearts full. Huge love to @_kirrrky_ and @el_beaux_ for facilitating such a mindful, welcoming space for us to dive into our imaginations.

Creating art together is such a gift, and being able to do this on Gadigal/Wangal Land, where creativity has thrived since time immemorial, is humbling. Always was, always will be Aboriginal land. ??

Until next time, stay inspired! ??? #CollageCommunity #CreativeWorkshop #QueerArt #AlwaysWasAlwaysWillBe #KaleidoscopeCollective

Book Launch Saturday! ???? 7 September 2024, 2-4pm at Frontyard, 228 Illawarra Road, Marrickville 2204 ???? with @jpgoetz and @emstew__

Jake Goetz will be launching his next collection of poems, Holocene Pointbreaks. Emily Stewart will give a short launch speech, and then Goetz will be reading from the book. All Welcome! 

Written amid the COVID lockdowns of 2020, Holocene Pointbreaks embraces the geographical restriction during that period to create a triptych of local meanderings; an archipelago of poetic islands that link three unique ecologies located on the Countries of the Dharawal and Eora Nations.

Artist talk at @frontyardorg, Friday, 26 July from 3-5pm! ??

This talk marks the end of Chris's week-long residency, where he's been creating large format black and white photographs. During the talk, Chris will demonstrate the main principles of large format photography, share the basics of exposure calculations, and explain his unique approach to making negatives using darkroom paper instead of traditional film sheets.

Join Frontyard resident camila kevorkian as she presents her work, An Anthology of Transit.

During her residency, camilia asked, “What does the Frontyard Library want to say?” She answered this through a series of conversations with and bodily experiences in the Frontyard library, which she documented through drawings and other media.

An Anthology of Transit takes place on Thursday, 25 July 2024, 5pm, at Frontyard (228 Illawarra Road, Marrickville). It is free.

Hi friends,

I am hosting another group Tarot reading session at Frontyard on Saturday May 4th 3-5pm. Come!   

This is the second in a series of readings focusing on a keyword. Last time, we spoke about PRECARITY, the guiding word for this session will be RAGE. See blurb below.

The way I practice Tarot is slightly different to a traditional Tarot reading. In a typical one-on-one reading, the querent (or questioner) comes to the reader with a problem for which they are seeking guidance. The reader lays out a spread and interprets the cards, tailoring the reading to the querent’s mindset.

I read with small and large groups of people. Together, we formulate a question based on our shared feelings, problems, and ideas. I facilitate the reading, but I try not to exert too much control. The best readings are collaborative and discursive. I like that Tarot opens a space for interpretation and negotiation. You don’t need to know much about Tarot to participate!

Rage has been plaguing me of late. In many ways, rage is the logical response to witnessing a genocide in real time. There’s a difference between anger and the tumultuous overflow of rage. Sometimes rage is energising and inspiring. Other times, rage can be misdirected or exhausting. You might feel like you’re spinning on the spot or launching into multiple directions at once. I think of bell hooks on ‘killing rage’ (1996) and anti-racist struggle. She reflects on dealing with rage over time C repressing it, unleashing it, fearing it, valuing it: “(rage) burns in my psyche with an intensity that creates clarity. It is a constructive healing rage.” What does it mean to honour rage? How to make the most of your rage? What are we doing in between intense bouts of rage?  

If any of this resonates with you, come along and we’ll work it out together. ?????

Artist Talk @frontyardorg
Thurs 14 Dec, 6-8pm

Jonah Brucker-Cohen is an award winning researcher, artist, and writer. His work focuses on the theme of “Deconstructing Networks” and includes hundreds of creative projects that critically challenge and subvert accepted perceptions of network interaction and experience. Exploring “Critical Networked Experiences” Jonah will discuss projects such as “BumpList”, an email community for the determined, “Weapon of Protest”, a modified game controller that protests gun violence in the US, “WordPlay”, an interactive literary hack using RFID and many more.

Links: http://www.coin-operated.com
Twitter / X: coinop29

We're Back! ?? Radio Insomnia on air during the night of the 15th of November to Thursday 16th from midnight to 6 a.m..!

Radio Insomnia returns to Eora/Sydney for a broadcast as part of (((Amplify: Story, Resistance, Radio)))’s takeover. The exhibition/pirate radio explores the importance of amplification and listening in urban politics.

We will be live from @frontyardorg with discussions and listening sessions. Join us in person, or online via our chatroom.

Nov 15th - 16th 2023
Midnight - 6 am (AEST; UTC+11)
Frontyard : 228 Illawarra Rd, Marrickville
Program and Tune in:
https://insomnia.radio.fm/

We’ve picked up some of the loose ends from our epic Montreal début, taking an opportunity to further explore Wakefulness as Resistance with night protest, and soft activism in wakefulness, in awakening against the silence of normalcy or for reconfiguring capitalist rhythms. For us, insomnia is political because it cannot let things rest.

We continue to explore the possibilities of radio as a medium, with insights from great artists on this side of the world, and we’ve also dug into some of the histories of night-time pirate radio broadcasting and listening. There will also be some durational compositions, as well as many late-night sonic incursions in between.

Hosted by @_ah_oui and @nicolasmontgermont with contributions by:

Sisters Akousmatika (Julia Drouhin & Pip Stafford), radio cegeste, diffusion fm (Hethre Contant & Jon Panther), ∏-node, Frances Barrett, Robert Curgenven, Debris Facility Pty Ltd, David Goren, Will Johncock, Tetsuo Kogawa, Tom Melick, Tom Roe, ?ther Varia, Matt Warren with Sally Ann McIntyre & Dani Kirby.

aka : @radioqueens, @cegeste, @jean_modification_diffusionfm, @hethre, @fffrancesfffrancis , @robertcurgenven, @debris.facility, @shortwaveology, @will_johncock, @tomroeradio, mattdwarren, @southernramble

Hi friends,

I am hosting a collective Tarot reading session at Frontyard on Sunday October 22nd 3-5pm. Come along!

In a typical Tarot reading, the querent (or questioner) comes to the reader with a problem for which they are seeking guidance. The reader lays out a spread and interprets the cards, tailoring the reading to the querent’s mindset. The ‘answer’ to the problem is in the work of interpretation.

To read Tarot with a larger group is to come together and invest in a shared problem. When I read with people, I try not to exert too much control. As a form of knowledge production, Tarot invites emotional and heuristic responses; it can be cathartic, illuminating, and unsettling. I like that Tarot opens a space for interpretation and negotiation. 

I am often preoccupied with the problem of precarity. In terms of labour, it is the persistent violence of casualisation C trying to build a life from gig work and short-term jobs. Is ‘security’ a pipedream? An illusion? A trap? What is precarity on a damaged planet? I often think of a quote from Anna Tsing: “precarity is not the exception but the condition of our time. Precarity is being vulnerable to others” (2015). Is it possible to embrace precarity is a less alienated way? If any of this resonates with you, let’s work it out together. ??

Night school - peer led learning time

How do we develop collaborative practices of care, pooling our obscure knowledge and abundances into nourishment?

We’ll do some mutating of paper
Some guided meditation
And some hot dialog

We will look at community currencies, cooperative structures, queer family, our porous bodies, cults, communes, community, cultures of extraction and discard, ways of accumulating wealth, ways of caring, the delusions of care, sauerkraut, the garden, effluence in concrete, pouring paper and the close space behind our eyelids.

We will look to each other for answers not expecting anything and knowing that we are held by our entire community's knowledge.
Annual AGM ???????

Letter writing alongside people in prison on Gadigal/Wangal Nura

Date: Sunday 11 June, 2023

Time: 2pm-4pm

Location: Frontyard Projects, 228 Illawarra Rd, Marrickville

Accessibility: Access information sent via email

RSVP via email: letterwritingsyd@gmail.com

IRL Prison Solidarity Network holds monthly get-togethers where we write to people inside. These monthly sessions are for people who write regularly, people who have been in prison, or friends or family of people inside. Come have a tea, snacks and a chat while we write together.

New and first-time letter writers are welcome to come along and bring a friend. If you are a new letter writer, please arrive at 2pm. At the start of the session, we will explore why we write, ethical considerations when writing to people inside, and you will have a chance to send one-off letters of solidarity.

On stolen unceded Gadigal and Wangal lands.
